23, from $508 million to $447
million, while the Dow Jones
dropped 24.9 percent and the
Standard and Poor's 500 Index
fell 22.9 percent.

securities, on the other hand,
grew in value over the same three
week period by 2.2 percent, a
figure roughly equal to the
growth of the Shearson Lehman
Government/Corporate Bond Index. Sunshine attributed the increase in value of these securities
to the simultaneous decline in interest rates.

Some college and university endowments took a
beating on Wall Street last week, but over all the losses
were not as severe as they might have been because
many institutions had followed conservative investment
strategies and sold their stocks before the market's nosedive.
John B. Cox, a spokesman for the National Association of College and University Business Officers, said
he believed the stock-market gyrations would have little impact on higher-education finances generally.
"College endowments are widely diversified, and, in
the main, they're conservatively managed," he said.
Furthermore, he noted, only a small percentage of the
nation's 3,300 colleges even have major endowments.
In the aggregate, endowments account for only a small
portion of college income. According to the latest federal
statistics, endowment income provided 5.3 per cent of
the revenue of private colleges and only 0.6 per cent

of the revenue of public ones in 1985-86.
Leigh A. Jones, vice-president for business and
finance at Berea College and chairman of the NACUBO
investment committee, said small endowments, which
typically are invested in fixed-income securities, should
not have been badly hurt by the October 19 stock-market
plunge. "Schools with a large commitment to equity
would have suffered the most, but they have also gained the most" from the rise in stock prices of recent years,
he said.

in the short-term losses on market value on the endowments, but the impact it will have on contributions,"
said Roderick MacDougall, the treasurer of Harvard
University. "A half a trillion dollars was taken out of
the economy."

Taking the RC Challenge
The Coalition for a Free South Africa has
achieved one of its goals—and named its
poison.
The recent decision by Auxiliary Enterprises
to provide Royal Crown Cola products on campus as well as the Coca-Cola products already
available is a move in the right direction for
the Coalition's Coke boycott campaign.
Although some Coalition members would
ultimately like Coke products to be eliminated
completely from campus, the present addition
of RC products is important because it will
allow people to choose between soft drink
brands. If public feeling against Coke becomes
strong enough, then the demand for RC will
grow and the supply of Coke will become increasingly limited.
If, however, a Coke boycott is unable to command the attention of the majority, then at least
an alternative is available for those who so
desire it.
This compromise, however, holds significance for much more than simply the provision
of a choice of soft drink brands on moral
grounds. It is a move which should be examined
with the Human Climate Task Force Report in
mind.
The Coalition had initially attempted to bring
Pepsi products to campus to replace Coke. This
is a logical choice because Pepsi is the nation's
"second" cola. Not only does Pepsi have wide
consumer recognition and is easily available,
but a switch on this campus from Coke to its
leading competitor might have been a slap in
the face for the Coca-Cola Company.

However, the attempted switch to Pepsi
wound up being as odious for some members
of the Jewish Students Association as the continued use of Coke was for the Coalition. In
an effort to prevent further discord, the Coalition sought a compromise which would suit the
interest of both organizations.
The mutual respect and understanding promoted by the Task Force Report has shown
through in the Coalition's willingness to meet
the needs of another campus group as well as
those of their own.
Furthermore, Coalition members and RC
organizers Paul Genest and Bijoy Mathew have
emphasized how pleased they were with the
cooperation they received from Auxiliary
Enterprises on this effort. That they were so
willing to give credit where credit was due further promotes a feeling of good will and
cooperation at Homewood.
Finally, the Coalition hopes to represent both
sides of the issue at its forthcoming forum on
the use of Coca-Cola products. They plan to
invite a Coca-Cola representative to speak as
well as a South African rights activist. This
balanced representation is an effective way of
encouraging people to learn more about CocaCola's involvement in South Africa.
The decision to bring RC to Hopkins is a win
for the Task Force Report as well as the Coalition. The methods used by the Coalition in striving for their cause may have forced them to
compromise a bit, but their efforts to cooperate
and accomodate the interests of others set a
solid example for other groups to follow.

Phil Gochenour:
by Phil Gochenour
One of the greatest things to
have emerged from the whole
punk movement was the notion of
experimentation. Our understanding of what actually constituted
a song, and our understhnding of
the nature of music, underwent
radical changes. Artists like
Laurie Anderson and Pere Ubu,
and albums like Lou Reed's
Metal Machine Music, showed us
that in every sound there is a kind
of music, and that any collection
of sounds might be a song.
Probably the most active group
today, in this respect, is Sonic
Youth. To Sonic Youth, the
guitar is merely an instrument for
creating sound, not some sacred
object that must be treated within
given parameters. In their quest
for the ultimate sounds, they have
bashed guitars (they say Fenders
hold up best), used screwdrivers
on the strings, inserted blocks of
wood under the bridges, and us-

The Flip Side

ed completely random tunings.
Now, you're asking, what does
all this sound like? It sounds pretty damn good, actually. On their
latest album, Sister, the opening
track, "Schizophrenia," could
pass for being a mellow, jangly,
Joy Division/Smiths kind of song,
if it weren't for the off-balanced
lyrics and the slight dissonance
within the guitar chords. This,
however, is just a way to ease you
into the madness that follows.
Each song on this album is, in its
own way, somewhat psychopathic, whether it's the repression of
."(I've got a) Catholic Block," or
the outright psycho-killer insanity of "Pacific Coast Highway."
Take the psycho, sometimes
cryptically disturbing lyrics, and
link them up with music that combines headlong speed, heavily
fuzzed guitars, and hound from
hell vocals and what do you get?
Tunes that will melt your brain
into a grey ooze. Yeah, it's that
good. Just one word of warning:

don't listen to this album under
the influence, or you just might
lose .your mind.
Okay, we should also discuss
the solo project of Lee Renaldo,
a guitarist with Sonic Youth. Mr.
Renaldo has taken a collection of
guitar sounds and put them onto
infinite tape loops, the result being the album From Here to Infinity. This is another mindbender of an album. The longest
track comes in at about 90
seconds, but each track ends with
a locked groove—the needle will
continue to play the last few
seconds of the track, presumably
indefinitely. This means you have
to lift the needle onto the next
track, if you want. That's the important thing, because this is an
album that completely pushes our
understanding of sound to the
limits. If you let the same track
run for, oh, say five minutes, you
begin hearing different things.
Sonically, the sounds are exactly
the same, but your ear begins to

interpret the sound differently.
Since each person hears differentr,
things, and since the sounds
change according to the speed at
which the record is played, and
the EQ setting, what you have is
an infinite number of sounds.
And yes, each track does sound
like something. In "Destruction
Site," you can hear the hammers
and power tools, while "Hard
Left" sounds like an instrumental song fragment.
This is not an album you can
passively listen to—what you put
into it is what you bring out of it.
For those willing to do the work,
there's an awful lot for you to
hear.
Both of these albums are on
SST Records, one of the few
labels around that really encourages and supports the more
experimental artists. Give'em a
listen.

by P. Sean Bramble
Across the history of the Steinbrenner Yankees a line can be
sharply drawn, and that line is not
too difficult to discern. And since
the line I wish to draw separates
the last Yankee pennant from the
futility of the past six years, it is
worth examining exactly what it
is that George has done wrong.
The Yankees of 1976-1981
were one of the most remarkable
dynasties of modern history, and
not simply because of their huge
success. Though they won five
divisional titles in six years, the
true mark that Steinbrenner left
upon baseball was his canny free
agent shopping. His big spending
was arrogant, it was also
capitalist, but it was also triumphant. By signing tremendous
amounts of free agents, he literally bought championships.
Whether this kind of action is
fair can be debated elsewhere.
What should be noted, though, is
the quality of the free agents
George signed. Roll the names
through the mind: Hunter,
Jackson, Gossage, John, Winfield. . .so many Hall of Famers.
Complemented with a talent base
of Munson, Chambliss, Nettles,
Rivers, Randolph, Dent, and
Guidry—players brought up from
the farm or acquired in trade—it
is readily apparent that what

George had done was buy insurance. By collecting a team and
a half, he thus bought his luck.
Fast forward to 1982. That was
the year in which, after seeing his
Yankees humiliated in the World
Series, George unveiled his new
Yankees, a Yankee team
predicated upon speed, not
power. It was this team that
featured Dave Collins and Ken
Griffey in the outfield. A washedup John Mayberry was brought in
to play first. A Met hero (Lee
Mazzilli) was signed. And the
projected rotation included Roger
Erickson and Mike Morgan.
The question is, were any of
these men conceivably great
players, of possible Hall of Fame
credentials? Of course not. What
Steinbrenner has done is forget
the means by which he won. Instead of pursuing great talent he
has bought anyone available.
Think of the marginal majorleaguers he has imported: Omar
Moreno, Steve Kemp, Dale
Berra, Toby Harrah, and Claudell
Washington, to name only a few.
To date, the only legitimately
great player George has acquired
is Rickey Henderson. Another
problem of George's is the shuffling of the personnel. The
Yankees of the 70's had welldefined positions, where
everyone knew where and how
often they would play. Partly that

is a tribute to the managerial skills
of Billy Martin, but not entirely;
Martin has managed the Yankees
twice in the 80's and he hasn't
been able to put an end to the
game of musical chairs. In 1983
they had a firstbaseman—
centerfielder (Griffey), a
firstbaseman—shortstop
(Smalley), and a firstbaseman—
rightfielder (Mattingly). Shane
Rawley, Dave Righetti, and
Charlie Hudson have never

known if they were to be in the
rotation or the bullpen. And as for
the managers, well you know that
story already.
These two problems are a good
part of the reason why the
Yankees have not won. I wish I
could say that George seems to
have learned his lesson, but I
don't think I can. So long as he
is more concerned with saving
